Authors:
Abel Ferreira Borges, Frâncisco De Alcântara Neto, Kedma da
Silva Matos, Jose Evandro Beserra Junior, Nelson Sidnei Massola Junior,
Silvino I. Moreira, Maruzanete Prereira Melo
Title:
Thielaviopsis ethacetica is the etiological agent of
sugarcane pineaple rot disease in Brazil
Keywords:
Thielaviopsis paradoxa Complex; Saccharum; pineapple
rot.
Abstract:
Sugarcane pineapple rot is an important sugarcane stem
disease, which also affects germination and sprouting. In Brazil, the
causal agent is the fungus Thielaviopsis paradoxa. However, recent
studies proved that T. paradoxa is a complex species composed of five
phylogenetic species. In this work, four Thielaviopsis strains obtained
from sugarcane stems and pineapple fruits were characterized using
molecular and morphological approaches. Primary and secondary conidia
were observed by bright field microscopic analysis. In the sexual
compatibility test, black perithecia with ascospore mass exudation at
the stem-neck were observed. According to phylogenetic analysis with ITS
and TEF1-α sequences, the strains were identified as T. ethacetica.
Inoculation test in sugarcane resulted in stem rot and in germination
and sprouting reduction. This is the first record of sugarcane stem rot
caused by T. ethacetica in Brazil.
